  "article_text": [
    "let @xmath0 be a group and @xmath1 be the infinite cyclic group generated by @xmath2 . for each @xmath3 ,",
    "let @xmath4 denote the homomorphism @xmath5 induced by taking the identity map on @xmath0 and sending @xmath6 .",
    "given an element @xmath7 of the free product @xmath8 , there is a corresponding function @xmath9 whose evaluation at @xmath3 is @xmath10 building on this notion , we write @xmath11 to represent a _ group equation _ in the single variable @xmath2 with coefficients in @xmath0 whose _ solution set _ is @xmath12 the solution set above is called the _ primitive solution set corresponding to @xmath7_.    the _ zariski topology _ ( or _ verbal topology _ as in @xcite ) on @xmath0 is defined by taking the collection of primitive solution sets to be a sub - basis for the closed sets of the topology .",
    "that is , each zariski - closed set of @xmath0 is of the form @xmath13 for some indexing set @xmath14 , where for each @xmath15 , the set @xmath16 is a finite union of primitive solution sets corresponding to ( single - variable ) group equations with coefficients in @xmath0 .",
    "note that in general , the zariski topology is not a group topology .",
    "the zariski topology ( and its more general form in @xcite ) is useful in bringing notions from algebraic geometry to the group theoretical setting in order to aid in the study of equations over groups .",
    "the topology is also useful in the study of topological groups : zariski - closed sets are closed in every @xmath17 group topology , and , in the case of countable groups , the zariski - closed sets are the only such sets @xcite . for some recent applications to topological groups , see @xcite and references therein .",
    "the following definition is motivated by the standard notion of an algebraic subgroup in algebraic geometry .    a zariski - closed subgroup ( or more generally , a subset ) of @xmath0",
    "is called _ algebraic_.    [ centalg ] for any subgroup @xmath18 , the centralizer @xmath19 is algebraic . in particular , @xmath20=1 \\}.\\ ] ]    in @xcite , kharlampovich and myasnikov show that given a torsion - free non - elementary hyperbolic group @xmath0 , any proper , first - order definable subgroup @xmath21 is cyclic . in the language of @xcite , @xmath0 is a domain , so any zariski - closed subset of @xmath0 may be expressed as an intersection of primitive solution sets . furthermore , since @xmath0 is equationally noetherian ( ( * ? ? ?",
    "* thm . 1.22 ) )",
    ", this intersection may be taken to be finite , so algebraic subgroups of @xmath0 are first - order definable , and in particular , the structural result from @xcite for definable subgroups of @xmath0 holds for algebraic subgroups . in this paper , we obtain a structural result for algebraic subgroups in the more general case when @xmath0 is an acylindrically hyperbolic group . before stating this result , we briefly discuss acylindrically hyperbolic groups .",
    "let @xmath0 be group acting on a metric space @xmath22 .",
    "note that in this paper , all actions of groups on metric spaces are assumed to be isometric .",
    "[ acyl ] the action of @xmath0 on @xmath23 is called _ acylindrical _ if for each @xmath24 there exist @xmath25 such that for every pair of points @xmath26 with @xmath27 , there are at most @xmath28 elements @xmath3 such that @xmath29 for example , every geometric ( i.e. proper and cobounded ) action is acylindrical . however , acylindricity is a much weaker condition .",
    "e.g. , every action on a bounded space is acylindrical .",
    "[ defn2 ] if @xmath23 is a hyperbolic space , then the action of @xmath0 on @xmath23 is called _ elementary _ if the limit set of @xmath0 on the gromov boundary @xmath30 contains at most @xmath31 points .    a group @xmath0 is called _ acylindrically hyperbolic _ if it admits a non - elementary acylindrical action on a hyperbolic space .",
    "( more about groups acting acylindrically on hyperbolic spaces , including other equivalent definitions of acylindrically hyperbolic groups , can be found in subsection [ acting acyl ] . for a more comprehensive discussion of acylindrically hyperbolic groups ,",
    "see @xcite . )",
    "the class of acylindrically hyperbolic groups contains many interesting examples , including non - elementary hyperbolic and relatively hyperbolic groups , infinite mapping class groups of punctured closed surfaces , @xmath32 for @xmath33 , directly indecomposable non - cyclic right angled artin groups , most @xmath34-manifold groups ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "* appendix ) for details ) , and groups of deficiency @xmath35 @xcite .",
    "[ non - elem ] given an acylindrically hyperbolic group @xmath0 , a subgroup @xmath18 is called _ non - elementary _ if for some acylindrical action of @xmath0 on a hyperbolic space @xmath23 , the action of @xmath36 on @xmath23 is non - elementary .",
    "let @xmath37 , where @xmath38 and @xmath39 is a free group of rank @xmath31 .",
    "then the action of @xmath0 on the bass - serre tree associated to the free product structure is acylindrical and non - elementary , but the induced action of @xmath36 is elementary .",
    "however , @xmath36 is a non - elementary subgroup of @xmath0 since there exists another acylindrical action of @xmath0 on a hyperbolic space ( namely the action of @xmath0 on its cayley graph with respect to the generating set @xmath40 ) such that @xmath36 acts non - elementarily .",
    "we are now ready to state the main result .    [",
    "main ] suppose that @xmath0 is an acylindrically hyperbolic group and that @xmath18 is non - elementary .",
    "then @xmath36 is algebraic if and only if @xmath36 is a virtual centralizer of some finite subgroup of @xmath0 .",
    "it should be noted that we actually prove a stronger version of the forward implication of theorem [ main ] ( see theorem [ strongmain ] ) which is a result about the zariski closure of non - elementary subgroups of acylindrically hyperbolic groups . in the course of proving theorem",
    "[ main ] , we obtain a technical result ( proposition [ coboundedness ] ) which seems to be of independent interest .    in the case where @xmath0 is torsion - free , any such virtual centralizer is the entire group @xmath0 . in particular ,",
    "if @xmath36 is an algebraic subgroup of a torsion - free non - elementary hyperbolic group @xmath0 , then either the action of @xmath36 on the cayley graph of @xmath0 is elementary ( in which case @xmath36 is either @xmath41 or infinite cyclic ) or @xmath42 , so theorem [ main ] recovers the structural result for algebraic subgroups implied by the result of kharlampovich and myasnikov in @xcite .",
    "theorem [ main ] also yields the following corollaries , which we prove in section [ appl ] :    [ freecor ] let @xmath43 and @xmath44 be nontrivial groups , and let @xmath36 be an algebraic subgroup of @xmath45 . then at least one of the following holds :    * @xmath36 is either infinite cyclic or isomorphic to @xmath46 , the infinite dihedral group .",
    "* @xmath36 is conjugate to a subgroup of either @xmath43 or @xmath44 .",
    "* @xmath47 .    in the more general case of torsion - free relatively hyperbolic groups ,",
    "we obtain the following .",
    "[ tfrhcor ] let @xmath0 be a torsion - free relatively hyperbolic group with peripheral subgroups @xmath48 , and let @xmath18 be an algebraic subgroup . then at least one of the following holds :    * @xmath42 .",
    "* @xmath36 is cyclic .",
    "* @xmath36 is conjugate to a subgroup of some @xmath49 .    furthermore , if ( c ) holds for an abelian @xmath49 , then either @xmath50 or @xmath36 is conjugate to @xmath49 .",
    "important examples of torsion - free relatively hyperbolic groups with abelian peripheral subgroups ( the so - called toral relatively hyperbolic groups ) include limit groups in the sense of sela and fundamental groups of hyperbolic knot compliments .",
    "limit groups are hyperbolic relative to their maximal abelian non - cyclic subgroups ( see ( * ? ? ?",
    "0.3 ) ) , while fundamental groups of hyperbolic knot compliments are hyperbolic relative to free abelian subgroups of rank @xmath31 ( cusp subgroups ; see @xcite ) .",
    "[ acccor ] let @xmath0 be an acylindrically hyperbolic group and let @xmath51 be an ascending chain of algebraic subgroups of @xmath0 .",
    "then either    * for each acylindrical action of @xmath0 on a hyperbolic space @xmath23 , the subgroup @xmath52 acts on @xmath23 with bounded orbits ( in particular , each @xmath53 is elliptic ) , or * the chain stabilizes .    note that in general , it is actually possible for an acylindrically hyperbolic group to have an ascending chain of ( elliptic ) algebraic subgroups which does not stabilize .",
    "example [ accex ] provides a construction of such a group .",
    "* acknowledgments .",
    "* i would like to thank denis osin for his guidance throughout this project , sahana balasubramanya for her careful reading and comments on a draft of this paper , and michael hull for a helpful discussion which led to the removal of some non - essential material .",
    "let @xmath0 be a group , and let @xmath1 be the infinite cyclic group generated by @xmath2 .",
    "notice that for two distinct elements @xmath54 , the equations @xmath55 and @xmath56 may have the same solution set .",
    "( for example , let @xmath57 for any @xmath58 . ) in this case we will regard the equations @xmath55 and @xmath56 as equivalent , as they both define the same subbasic closed set of the zariski topology .",
    "it is helpful , given a ( not necessarily finite ) generating set @xmath59 of @xmath0 , to view an element @xmath58 as a word in the elements of @xmath60 and their inverses .",
    "in particular , note that for any cyclic reduction @xmath61 of the word @xmath7 , @xmath11 and @xmath62 are the same equation and that therefore , we may always assume that the word on the left - hand side of an equation is cyclically reduced .",
    "[ multhomeom ] viewing each @xmath58 as a word in @xmath63 allows us to observe that for any @xmath3 , the map @xmath9 given by left ( similarly , right ) multiplication by @xmath64 is a homeomorphism with respect to the zariski topology . in particular , for each @xmath3 and each word @xmath58 , let @xmath65 be the word obtained from @xmath7 by replacing each instance of the letter @xmath2 with @xmath66 and each instance of the letter @xmath67 with @xmath68 , and note that if @xmath23 is the solution set of the equation @xmath11 , then @xmath69 is the solution set of the equation @xmath70 .",
    "[ finindalg ] if a subgroup @xmath18 contains a finite index algebraic subgroup @xmath43 , then @xmath36 is also algebraic .",
    "@xmath36 is a finite union of cosets @xmath71 ( @xmath72 ) , each of which is algebraic by remark [ multhomeom ] .",

[ defn1 ] given a group @xmath0 acting on a hyperbolic space @xmath23 , an element @xmath3 is called _ loxodromic _ if the map @xmath112 given by @xmath113 is a quasi - isometric embedding for some ( equivalently , any ) @xmath114 .",
    "each loxodromic element @xmath3 has exactly two limit points @xmath115 on the gromov boundary @xmath30 .",
    "a pair of loxodromic elements @xmath116 are called _ independent _ if the sets @xmath117 and @xmath118 are disjoint .",
    "the following definition is due to bestvina and fujiwara in @xcite :    for a group @xmath0 acting on a metric space @xmath23 , an element @xmath119 satisfies the _ weak proper discontinuity _ condition ( or @xmath87 is a _ wpd element _ ) if for each @xmath24 and each @xmath120 there exists @xmath121 such that @xmath122 let @xmath123 denote the set of elements @xmath3 which are loxodromic wpd with respect to the action of @xmath0 on @xmath23 .",
    "it is easy to see that if @xmath0 acts acylindrically ( as in definition [ acyl ] ) and @xmath23 is a hyperbolic space , then every loxodromic element is a wpd element .",

    "* thm . 1.1 ) ) let @xmath0 be a group acting acylindrically on a hyperbolic space . then @xmath0 satisfies exactly one of the following three conditions :    1 .",
    "g has bounded orbits .",
    "g is virtually cyclic and contains a loxodromic element .",
    "g contains infinitely many independent loxodromic elements .",
    "if @xmath0 has bounded orbits , @xmath0 is called _",
    "elliptic_.    [ loxrem ] in light of definitions",
    "[ defn2 ] and [ defn1 ] , theorem [ actions ] tells us that if a group @xmath0 acts acylindrically on a hyperbolic space @xmath23 , then the action is non - elementary if and only if @xmath0 is not virtually cyclic and contains at least one loxodromic element .",
    "[ ah ] ( ( * ? ? ?",
    "1.2 ) ) for any group @xmath0 , the following conditions are equivalent :    1 .   @xmath0 admits a non - elementary acylindrical action on a hyperbolic space .",
    "there exists a generating set @xmath59 of @xmath0 such that the corresponding cayley graph @xmath137 is hyperbolic , @xmath138 , and the natural action of @xmath0 on @xmath137 is acylindrical .",
    "@xmath0 is not virtually cyclic and admits an action on a hyperbolic space such that at least one element of @xmath0 is loxodromic and satisfies the wpd condition .",
    "4 .   @xmath0 contains a proper , infinite , hyperbolically embedded subgroup .",
    "a group @xmath0 is called _ acylindrically hyperbolic _ if it satisfies one of the four equivalent conditions above .",
    "the proof of our main result relies on the existence of arbitrarily large finite collections of loxodromic elements in the non - elementary subgroup @xmath36 with certain useful properties .",
    "lemma [ hlem ] guarantees these elements , provided we can find a generating set of @xmath0 satisfying the requisite assumptions . to find such a generating set , we prove proposition [ coboundedness ] , which also seems to be of independent interest .    [ coboundedness ]",
    "suppose that a group @xmath0 acts on a hyperbolic space @xmath23 and that @xmath36 is a subgroup of @xmath0 such that @xmath36 is not virtually cyclic and @xmath139 .",
    "then there exists a generating set @xmath59 of @xmath0 such that the cayley graph @xmath140 is hyperbolic , the action of @xmath0 on @xmath140 is acylindrical , and the action of @xmath36 on @xmath140 is non - elementary .    to prove proposition [ coboundedness ] , we need three other results .",

    "below is a well - known result that we will utilize in the proof of theorem [ main ] :    [ centralizer ] for any group @xmath0 , any subgroup @xmath18 , and any finite subset @xmath307 which is normalized by @xmath36 , the centralizer @xmath308 of @xmath309 in @xmath36 has finite index in @xmath36 .    since @xmath309 is normalized by @xmath36 , @xmath36 acts on @xmath309 by conjugation , yielding a natural homomorphism @xmath310 .",
    "the kernel of this homomorphism is precisely @xmath308 and has index in @xmath36 equal to the order of the image of @xmath36 in @xmath311 , which is finite since @xmath311 is finite",
    ".    we can now prove theorem [ main ] :    to show the forward implication , observe that @xmath312 by theorem [ strongmain ] so that in particular , @xmath313 .",
    "( apply theorem [ strongmain ] to the case where @xmath36 is its own zariski closure . ) then , by lemma [ centralizer ] , we have that @xmath313 is of finite index in @xmath36 .",
    "to show the reverse implication , we simply note that example [ centalg ] and corollary [ finindalg ] together imply that virtual centralizers of finite subgroups are always algebraic .",
    "let @xmath314 be the bass - serre tree corresponding to the graph of groups with vertex groups @xmath43 and @xmath44 and trivial edge group .",
    "it is easy to see that the natural action of @xmath45 on @xmath314 is acylindrical .",
    "( this is a particular case of ( * ? ? ? *",
    ") by theorem [ main ] , either the action of @xmath36 on @xmath314 is elementary , or @xmath36 is a virtual centralizer of some finite subgroup of @xmath45 .    before addressing each case , it will be helpful to recall the kurosh subgroup theorem @xcite , which states that any subgroup @xmath315 of @xmath45 decomposes as a free product @xmath316 where @xmath74 freely generates a subgroup of @xmath0 , for all @xmath15 we have @xmath317 and @xmath318 , and for all @xmath319 we have @xmath320 and @xmath321 .",
    "assume first that @xmath36 acts elementarily on @xmath314 .",
    "then by theorem [ actions ] , either @xmath36 is virtually cyclic and contains a loxodromic element or @xmath36 acts on @xmath314 with bounded orbits .",
    "if @xmath36 is virtually cyclic , then since @xmath36 decomposes as a free product as in ( [ kurosh ] ) , it must be that either @xmath322 or @xmath36 is equal to just a single factor of the free product in ( [ kurosh ] ) . in the latter case ,",
    "either @xmath323 ( in which case @xmath36 is cyclic ) , or @xmath36 is conjugate to a subgroup of either @xmath43 or @xmath44 ( which is not possible if @xmath36 contains a loxodromic element since conjugates of @xmath43 and @xmath44 are vertex stabilizers of @xmath314 and hence act with bounded orbits ) .",
    "if @xmath36 acts with bounded orbits , then by ( * ? ?",
    "2.8 ) , @xmath36 fixes a point in @xmath314 .",
    "since the edge stabilizers of @xmath314 are trivial and the vertex stabilizers of @xmath314 are conjugates of @xmath43 and @xmath44 , @xmath36 is conjugate to a subgroup of either @xmath43 or @xmath44 .",

    "otherwise , the action of @xmath36 on @xmath387 is elementary .",

    "[ accex ] consider a group with presentation @xmath403 that contains an infinite ascending chain of subgroups @xmath404 where for each @xmath368 , @xmath405 .",

    "hence there exists @xmath425 such that @xmath426 for all @xmath427 , where @xmath428 is a finite index subgroup of @xmath429 , so the chain @xmath51 must stabilize ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> a subgroup of a group @xmath0 is called _ algebraic _ if it can be expressed as a finite union of solution sets to systems of equations . </S>",
    "<S> we prove that a non - elementary subgroup of an acylindrically hyperbolic group is algebraic if and only if it is a virtual centralizer of a finite subgroup . </S>",
    "<S> we provide some applications of this result to free products , torsion - free relatively hyperbolic groups , and ascending chains of algebraic subgroups in acylindrically hyperbolic groups .    </S>",
    "<S> * msc subject classification : * 20f70 , 20f67 , 20f65 . </S>"
  ]
}
